before a special jury. The circumstances were as follow :
Both the defendant and prosecutor are members of the
Cocoa Tree Club, in St. James’-street, Piccadilly, and
on the 8th of December, 1884, they played at cards

should be played for on a future evening, They subse-
quently played a few games, when Mr, Alexander won
ar. additional £200, and the defendant paid him £500,
the balance standing over. A fow weeks afterwards Mr,
Legg, according to his affidavit, heard that Mr, Alex-
ander had been accused of cheating a Mr. Wyndham of
£550 at cards, at the Road Club, in January, 1885, and
on the 18th of February the defendant wrote a letter
to the committes of the Cocoa Tree Club to
the offect that Mr. Harold Alexander had been com-
pelled to resign his membership of the Road Club,
having been detected at cheating at cards, aud that he
was prepared to prove this charge, This was the libel
complained of, and for which he was committed for
trial, but was allowed to stand out on his own recog«
nisanees of £50, The matter now came before this

opposed by Mr, Gill, to expedite the hearing of the,
rule for the certiorari, in order that the’ trial might.
take place before the prosecutor had to rejoin his regi-.
ment in India, The Court, disapproving of the course.
taken by the prosecutor in instituting criminal pro--

At the Hull Police-court, on Thursday, a young girl
named Isabella Hewson was charged with the murder
of her illegitimate child by hanging it, On her brother
being called she became terribly excited, shrieked out
the name of her child, and went into several fits, She
was go violent that two female warders and sevoral
officera had to hold her. The hearing of the case had
to be suspended, . .
